prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB1 Polarization Band3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 3 continuum for the polarization observations under the ToO mode for a bright GRB afterglow

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request to use the Band 3 continuum for the polarization observations under the ToO mode for a bright GRB afterglow, which could be observed as a point object. Hence any configuration is acceptable. The primary goal is to locate the Faraday depolarization in Band 3 for estimating E_(AG,h) and to address the location of the synchrotron peak in the spectrum by using broadband photometry for the measurement of E_AG. Figure 1 shows the expected polarization degree, which is entirely dependent on the segment of synchrotron radiation characterized by the synchrotron self-absorption, the peak frequency, and the Faraday frequency. The peak frequency shift to the low-frequency side along with the time since the burst (Figure 2, left). Therefore, Band 3 is the most suitable observation band for conducting polarimetry. Because the peak of the synchrotron flux will pass through Band3 around ~5 days after the burst, we can observe the afterglow around the flux maximum. This is also fully compatible with the technical containments of the ALMA observation in Cycle 2. Another advantage of using Band3 is the high sensitivity throughout the observation band, which has polarization capabilities. In addition, the expected polarization degree changes ~1.4 times after passing through the peak frequency in Band 3 and becomes similar to the observed values in optical (~2%). Hence, the expected polarization degrees for the current standard model (mid panel of Figure 1) are 1.4 % at v_Band3 < v_spectrum-peak (Figure 1, mid-left) and 2.0% at v_Band3 > v_spectrum-peak (e.g. Figure 1, mid-right), respectively.
We will select suitably bright events to efficiently conduct polarimetry by using multi-frequency coordinated observations, including rapid SMA submillimeter follow-ups. By using our SMA programs, we will be able to identify submillimeter afterglows brighter than ~3 mJy at 230 GHz, which is suitable for conducting polarimetric observations with ALMA. Because the brightness of optical afterglow and bright radio/submillimeter afterglow detection rate are correlated (Figure 3) [e.g. [12, 16, 17], we will also use the brightness of afterglows in optical bands. The Swift GRB satellite will mainly detect our targets in X-ray and γ-ray. By using their automatic GRB position alert, we will perform quick optical and OIR follow-up observations using our own follow-up network. Then we will select GRBs that have bright optical (e.g., r<18~20 at 0.2~0.5days) or IR (e.g. K<16-18 mag at 0.2~0.5 days) afterglows. Because OIR observations and related quick analysis can be completed within 1-2 hrs after the burst, we will trigger the SMA ToO within several hours (the fastest case) or ~0.5 after the burst. These efforts will provide submillimeter detections from an early phase. In addition, we will also use other radio follow-up results reported to the GCN circular.
After we have identified suitable events through our follow-ups (including additional results), we will trigger this proposed ALMA observation. We expect to execute our observation 3~7 days after the triggering ToO to observe afterglow around the flux peak (at 5~10 days after GRB). With our GRB ToO program in Cycle 1, the observations were successful 5 days after the triggering of our ToO according to the project trucker of ALMA. Hence, we are expecting the similar observational process. But we also understand the operation policy of the ToO in Cycle 2. A 2-week delay is also considered.
The expected brightness of the selected afterglows at 10 days after GRBs is 3~5 mJy at Band 3, which can be conducted at a polarization degree of 1.4% with better than 5.6σ confidence level by 3.0 hrs on source time (5.64 hrs in total including overhead). The observation time is estimated using the Observing Tool. With this observation, we can also obtain a polarization limit of 0.75% at a 3σ confidence level, which is deep enough to constrain the hidden electron.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB1 Photometry Band4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This will be a group of photometric observation with Band3, Band 6 and Band 7 to constrain the flux peak of synchrotron radiation from GRB afterglow.We prefer to make all 4-band photometric observation on the same night or with continuous 2 days.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request to use the Band 4 continuum for quality photometry (SNR~25 or better) of GRB afterglow under the ToO mode. This will be a group of observation with Band 6 and Band 7. The object is a point object, and any configuration of ALMA can perform this observations. The primary goal of this observation is to confirm the location of the spectrum peak frequency by constructing the broadband spectral energy distribution. This requested Band 4 photometry will be used with the Band3 polarization mode and additional photometry with Band 6 and Band7. Therefore, coincident observations with other bands within 1-2 days are desired. If we can make all of observations in the same night, it will be the perfect case.
A separated observation into the polarization mode and photometric mode is also acceptable. In this case, we prefer to execute the polarization mode first and the photometric mode will follow. In addition, we prefer to add additional Band3 photometric mode if the separation interval will be longer than 3 days. The separation interval of up to 5~7 days is also acceptable if we can execute the other Band3 photometric mode to constrain the broadband SED.
The target is exactly same with that of the Band 3 polarization mode described above. The expected faintest brightness in the Band 4 is 1~3 mJy. Thus, additional quality photometry (SNR~25) with Band 4 can be performed with short exposure such as 7.4 min on-source time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB1 Photometry Band3 (optional)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is the optional request when we need to separate observation into the polarization mode and the photometric mode with separation interval of longer than 3 days.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is the optional request when we need to separate observation into the polarization mode and the photometric mode with separation interval of longer than 3 days. The primary goal of this observation is to confirm the location of the spectrum peak frequency by constructing the broadband spectral energy distribution using photometry with Band 3, 4, 6, and 7. Because our target is time-variable object, the separation interval is critical to obtain broadband SED completely. If we can make all of observations in the same night or with continuous 2 days, it will be the perfect case. In this case, we will turn down this request.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to conduct the first linear polarization follow-ups with ALMA for constraining of mass of Gamma-Ray Burst (GRB) progenitor stars. Intensive optical afterglow observations showed the evidences that GRBs are produced when stars much more massive than the Sun are depleted nuclear fuel and explode. Moreover, the discovery of the GRB at the re-ionization epoch (z~8) suggests that the progenitors may be related to the first generation stars, whose mass estimation is a major topic of astrophysics. The masses of progenitor of 40 solar-mass is widely used in the numerous theoretical models, in which all of the electrons are energized by the relativistic shock and emit the synchrotron radiation as afterglow. However, substantial fraction of the electrons likely remains cool and shows non-observable radiation. These hidden electrons increase the total energy and scale of progenitor stars. Linear polarizations in the ALMA Band-3 is essential to discover these hidden electrons, because the Faraday rotation effect by the hidden electrons within the emitting source can be observable with Band-3 and the effects by the energized relativistic electrons are ignorable.
